Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope with Energy-Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy for Research, Undergraduate Training, and Curricular Enhancement
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Knox College in Galesburg, Illinois to provide instrument-based research training and hands-on classroom experimentation for undergraduate students through the acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope with Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy. The new instrument will help to prepare students in Environmental Studies, Biology, Chemistry, Physics and Neuroscience for more advanced science degrees and research careers. The instrument will also be available for use by local community college students and faculty for additional scientific training and data acquisition. In addition, the new instrument will be used for outreach into local K-12 classrooms via remote image access as well as through Knox's yearly summer youth program, College 4 Kids. Through these outreach activities, the project will increase area students' interest and confidence in studying the sciences.

The research uses of the instrument will be many and will vary across disciplines, with researchers from multiple departments at Knox and Monmouth Colleges making use of new capabilities including digital image capture, higher-resolution imaging, automated stage rotation, and elemental analysis. Research uses will include imaging newly-created hydrogels for characterization, examining fern gametophyte development and glial cell morphology, performing elemental analysis of archaeological ceramics and wetland rocks for the purposes of sourcing and interpreting environments of deposition, capturing images for 3D-printing of fish jaws, as well as digital imaging of microscopic invertebrates from soils and other environments. Researchers will be able to accurately image, measure and share data from a variety of microscopic samples, vastly increasing data accessibility as well as our understanding of small-scale processes across the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award enabled the acquisition, installation and utilization of a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) for the Environmental Studies, Biology, and Chemistry Departments at Knox College, as well as a biologist at Monmouth College. The new SEM, equipped with an Energy-Dispersive X-ray Spectrometer (EDS) and cold stage, replaced an aging instrument that no longer met the needs of the involved departments and programs. The instrument has directly contributed to research activities and curricular needs in biology, chemistry and environmental studies at Knox College. This instrument has strengthened faculty research programs and facilitated hands-on access by undergraduates in research training as well as in the laboratory curriculum.

 

Over the course of the grant period, whenever possible given instrument down time and pandemic limitations, the SEM has been heavily used for both research initiatives and curricular needs. Several ongoing faculty research projects utilized the new SEM:  PI Adelsberger made advances on two projects, both using the EDS for geochemical identification and the microscope for textural analysis. The projects include plaster analysis from Tall Dhiban, Jordan, and ironstone characterization from the Western Desert of Egypt; both of these are nearing publishable results, and PI Adelsberger gave one relevant conference presentation. Co-PI Gidmark?s work on fish anatomy has involved a team of students who have presented their work at national meetings, producing four different citations of student authored conference presentations. Co-PI Mehl has successfully used the SEM and its cold stage to investigate the ultrastructure of a new class of protein-based hydrogel polymers; two senior chemistry majors have engaged in Honors theses on these investigations. Co-PI Penick has conducted preliminary investigations of glial cells using the SEM, involving one student researcher; Monmouth College Senior Personnel Engstrom was trained on the instrument but has not had the chance to begin a research program due to pandemic-related visitor restrictions at Knox College. A total of 9 individual students have had hands-on access to the instrument as part of these research initiatives; 4 of these research students have graduated from Knox College. Of these graduates, 3 have gone on to graduate programs and one is applying to medical school. Additionally, results from these research initiatives were presented at several scientific meetings; these projects resulted in 4 student presentations and 1 faculty presentation at regional and national conferences. A number of students have utilized the SEM as part of hands-on laboratory activities over the grant period through curricular offerings in Biology and Environmental Studies, with a combined enrollment of 173 student seats over four academic trimesters. Finally, a number of faculty and staff have been trained on this instrument for a variety of uses, including 7 Knox College faculty and one Monmouth College faculty member. On-site Zeiss training took place soon after installation and was completed during the summer of 2020.

 

In summary, the acquisition of this new SEM with EDS has greatly improved our ambitious research and research training programs in Biology, Environmental Studies, and Chemistry, and has allowed greater implementation of this instrument in our Biology and Environmental Studies curriculum. It will extend a curricular collaboration to Monmouth College in the coming year. The hands-on training this instrument has provided, and will continue to provide in coming years, is an invaluable part of our student?s research experience, and makes them stronger candidates to graduate programs after graduation.
